llm_response.description: The retinal fundus image shows multiple dark spots consistent with microaneurysms and dot hemorrhages scattered throughout the retina. There are also several larger blot hemorrhages visible. Cotton wool spots are present, indicating localized retinal ischemia. There is no clear evidence of neovascularization or significant venous beading. Hard exudates are not prominently visible in this image.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. There are no visible signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. The blood vessels appear normal without any venous beading or neovascularization. There are no cotton wool spots present.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. There are visible blood vessels radiating from the optic disc. No obvious microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or neovascularization are present. There are no visible cotton wool spots or venous beading. A small area of hard exudates is visible near the macula.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. The blood vessels appear normal with no signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. There are no visible cotton wool spots, venous beading, or neovascularization. The overall appearance suggests a healthy retina with no evident signs of diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows the optic disc and macula. There are visible blood vessels radiating from the optic disc. There are no obvious signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. The image does not show clear evidence of neovascularization, cotton wool spots, or venous beading. The overall appearance suggests a lack of significant diabetic retinopathy changes.

The retinal fundus image shows several dark spots suggestive of microaneurysms and possible hemorrhages in the central region. There are no visible signs of exudates, cotton wool spots, or neovascularization. The optic disc appears normal, and the blood vessels do not show significant venous beading or dilation.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and the surrounding retina. There are no visible signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, exudates, cotton wool spots, venous beading, or neovascularization. The blood vessels appear normal without any significant abnormalities.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. There are no visible microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. The blood vessels appear normal without signs of venous beading or neovascularization. There are no cotton wool spots or other lesions indicative of diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows multiple bright spots consistent with hard exudates, primarily located in the central and mid-peripheral regions. There are also several dark red spots that could represent microaneurysms or small hemorrhages. The optic disc appears normal in color and size, and the macula is not clearly visible. There is no obvious neovascularization or cotton wool spots present.

The retinal fundus image shows several signs indicative of diabetic retinopathy. There are multiple microaneurysms visible as small red dots scattered throughout the retina. Hemorrhages are present, appearing as darker red spots. There are also hard exudates, which are yellowish-white lesions, indicating lipid deposits. Cotton wool spots, which are soft white patches, are visible, suggesting localized ischemia. No significant neovascularization is observed. The optic disc appears normal, and the macula is not clearly affected by any severe lesions.

The retinal fundus image shows the optic disc on the left with clear margins. There are visible blood vessels radiating from the optic disc. In the central region, there are multiple small yellowish-white spots suggestive of hard exudates. These are located near the macula, indicating possible macular edema. There are also several small red dots scattered throughout the retina, which are likely microaneurysms. No large hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, venous beading, or neovascularization are observed.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. The blood vessels appear normal with no signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. There are no visible cotton wool spots, venous beading, or neovascularization. The overall appearance suggests a healthy retina with no evident signs of diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows several signs indicative of diabetic retinopathy. There are multiple microaneurysms visible as small red dots scattered throughout the retina. Hemorrhages are present, appearing as larger, darker red spots. There are also hard exudates, which are yellowish-white lesions, indicating lipid deposits. Cotton wool spots, which are soft, white patches, suggest localized ischemia. No significant neovascularization is observed. The optic disc appears normal, and the macula is slightly blurred, possibly due to edema.

The retinal fundus image shows multiple bright yellow-white spots consistent with hard exudates, primarily located in the central and temporal regions. There are also several dark red spots indicative of microaneurysms and possible dot hemorrhages scattered throughout the retina. No signs of neovascularization or cotton wool spots are visible. The optic disc appears normal, and the macula is not clearly visible due to the presence of exudates.

The retinal fundus image shows multiple bright yellow-white spots, likely representing hard exudates, scattered in the central and mid-peripheral regions. There are also several dark red spots, which may indicate microaneurysms or small hemorrhages. The optic disc appears normal, and there is no obvious neovascularization or cotton wool spots visible. The presence of these features suggests non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows multiple microaneurysms and dot hemorrhages scattered throughout the retina. There are also several hard exudates visible, particularly in the superior region. Cotton wool spots are present, indicating localized ischemia. The optic disc appears slightly blurred, and there is evidence of venous beading. No neovascularization is observed.

The retinal fundus image shows multiple hard exudates arranged in a circinate pattern, which are bright yellow-white lesions. There are no visible microaneurysms or hemorrhages. The optic disc appears normal, and there is no evidence of neovascularization or cotton wool spots. The presence of these exudates suggests some level of diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows multiple yellowish-white spots in the macular region, indicative of hard exudates. There are also several small red dots scattered throughout the retina, suggestive of microaneurysms. No obvious signs of neovascularization, cotton wool spots, or venous beading are observed. The optic disc appears normal.

The retinal fundus image shows the optic disc on the left with clear margins. There are visible blood vessels radiating from the optic disc. In the central and right regions of the image, there are multiple yellowish-white spots indicative of hard exudates. These are located in the macular area, suggesting the presence of diabetic macular edema. There are no obvious signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, venous beading, or neovascularization visible in this image.

The retinal fundus image shows the presence of several microaneurysms and dot hemorrhages scattered throughout the retina. The optic disc appears normal, and the macula is not clearly affected by any lesions.

The retinal fundus image shows several signs indicative of diabetic retinopathy. There are multiple microaneurysms visible as small red dots scattered throughout the retina. Hemorrhages are present, appearing as larger, darker red spots. There are also hard exudates, which are yellowish-white lesions, indicating lipid deposits. Cotton wool spots, which are soft, fluffy white patches, are also visible, suggesting nerve fiber layer infarctions. The optic disc appears normal, and there is no evidence of neovascularization or significant venous beading.

There is evidence of venous beading and possible neovascularization near the optic disc, which are indicative of proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. The blood vessels appear normal with no signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. There are no visible cotton wool spots, venous beading, or neovascularization. The overall appearance suggests a healthy retina with no evident signs of diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows multiple hard exudates clustered in the macular region, indicating significant lipid leakage. There are also signs of microaneurysms and possible dot hemorrhages scattered throughout the retina. No clear evidence of neovascularization or cotton wool spots is visible. The presence of these features suggests moderate non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy.
